001package org.consensusj.jsonrpc;
002
003import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.DeserializationFeature;
004import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JavaType;
005import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;
006import java.util.Base64;
007
008// TODO: Rather than implementing transport (HttpUrlConnection vs. java.net.http) with subclasses use composition
009// In other words, the constructor should take a transport implementation object.
010// We're overusing inheritance in this hierarchy. We are breaking Effective Java, Item 18: Favor composition over inheritance.
011// We're using inheritance to configure:
012// A. The set of JSON-RPC methods that are supported, e.g. `getblockcount()` (which creates potential conflicts with `send()` etc)
013// B. The JSON mapping implementation. Which for now and the foreseeable future is Jackson only.
014// C. The transport implementation.
015//
016// As we want to support both HttpUrlConnection vs. java.net.http while transitioning to java.net.http, we don't want to force
017// subclasses like `BitcoinClient` to choose one or the other. So making (C) transport implementation a separate, composable object
018// is the FIRST STEP. Later we can look at separating (A) and (B). My first thoughts on how to do this is:
019// (1) Create a JsonRpcClientTransport interface.
020// (2) Rename `AbstractRpcClient` to `DefaultJsonRpcClient`, make it concrete and have it take a JsonRpcClientTransport instance as
021//     a constructor parameter.
022// (3) Create two implementations of `JsonRpcClientTransport` based upon `JsonRpcClientHttpUrlConnection` and `JsonRpcClientJavaNet`.
023// (4) Optional. Maybe look at extracting a class with some common "mapper" functions between the two transport implementations
024//
025// To separate (C) the easiest way is probably via a constructor parameter.
026// The proper separation for (A) is probably a complete separation. There should be no required inheritance to implement
027// a client with a set of methods. Internally the client would have a transport and a mapper and those could optionally be made available
028// via some accessor methods if the client application deems necessary.
029// At the heart of (B) (at least as currently implemented) is the mapping from a Java (or Groovy) method name to (i) a JSON-RPC method
030// name, (ii) optional parameter type-conversion for JSON serialization in the request, and (iii) type mapping for the deserialization
031// of the `result` field in the JsonRpcResponse<RSLT>. It might be helpful to think of this as two functional mappings:
032// (1) Map Java method name and parameters to a JSON-RPC request (either map to set of Java Objects _or_ all the way to JSON)
033// (2) Map from received JSON-RPC response to JsonRpcResponse<RSLT> -- this response mapper function is configured as part of making the request.
034//
035// The SECOND STEP is to abstract the specifics of Jackson from the (two) transport implementations. Basically methods/functions to
036// map from request to string/stream and to map from string/stream to response.  The java.net.http implementation has already defined
037// some functional interfaces for this, so coming up with an interface that both the java.net.http implementation and the HttpUrlConnection
038// implementation can use will lead to this "SECOND STEP"
039/**
040 * Abstract Base class for a strongly-typed, Jackson-based JSON-RPC client. Most of the work is done
041 * in default methods in {@link JacksonRpcClient} This abstract class implements the constructors, static fields, and
042 * getters, but leaves the core {@code sendRequestForResponse} method as {@code abstract} to be implemented by subclasses
043 * allowing implementation with alternative HTTP client libraries.
044 */
045public abstract class AbstractRpcClient implements JacksonRpcClient {
046    /**
047     * The default JSON-RPC version in JsonRpcRequest is now '2.0', but since most
048     * requests are created inside {@code RpcClient} subclasses, we'll continue to default
049     * to '1.0' in this base class.
050     */
051    private static final JsonRpcMessage.Version DEFAULT_JSON_RPC_VERSION = JsonRpcMessage.Version.V1;
052
053    protected final JsonRpcMessage.Version jsonRpcVersion;
054    protected final ObjectMapper mapper;
055    private final JavaType defaultType;
056
057    public AbstractRpcClient(JsonRpcMessage.Version jsonRpcVersion) {
058        this.jsonRpcVersion = jsonRpcVersion;
059        mapper = new ObjectMapper();
060        // TODO: Provide external API to configure FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES
061        mapper.configure(DeserializationFeature.FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES, false);
062        defaultType = mapper.getTypeFactory().constructType(Object.class);
063    }
064
065    @Override
066    public JsonRpcMessage.Version getJsonRpcVersion() {
067        return jsonRpcVersion;
068    }
069
070    @Override
071    public ObjectMapper getMapper() {
072        return mapper;
073    }
074
075    @Override
076    public JavaType getDefaultType() {
077        return defaultType;
078    }
079
080    /**
081     * Encode username password as Base64 for basic authentication
082     * <p>
083     * We're using {@link java.util.Base64}, which requires Android 8.0 or later.
084     *
085     * @param authString An authorization string of the form `username:password`
086     * @return A compliant Base64 encoding of `authString`
087     */
088    protected static String base64Encode(String authString) {
089        return Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString(authString.getBytes()).trim();
090    }
091}
